description: Entangled globe up to 24 cm diameter of tightly curled ruffled branches. Flat wavy lobes resembling lasagna pasta or cauliflower, creamy white to pale yellow. Cream spore print. Note: North American species are S. americana (eastern) or S. radicata (Pacific Northwest/western).
habitat: Parasitic/saprobic on roots and bases of conifer trees (pine, spruce, cedar, larch, fir) and hardwoods (especially oak). Prefers mature conifer stands with well-drained acidic soils, often on forest edges.
season: Fall through early spring. Late summer and early fall (August-October) is prime season. Pacific Northwest: Fall, Southeastern US: September-October.
lookalikes: No known toxic lookalikes - very distinctive appearance
safety_notes: Edible when young and fresh. Requires very thorough cleaning as debris traps in many folds. Older specimens become tough. Distinctive appearance makes identification relatively safe with no known poisonous lookalikes.
